importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the Tel Aviv soccer derby cancellation, marking a significant event in Israeli sports and public order.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period leading up to and including the match day, when tensions and security concerns peaked.

keyTakeAways: The Tel Aviv soccer derby between Hapoel and Maccabi was canceled due to violent riots and public disorder, with police reporting injuries to 12 civilians and 3 officers, and 9 arrests.
Police cited the endangerment of human life as the reason for canceling the match, citing pyrotechnics and smoke grenades thrown by fans.
Hapoel criticized the police response, calling it excessive and suggesting it showed a militarization of public order during a sporting event.
This incident follows a previous ban of Maccabi fans from attending a Europa League match in England due to security concerns, which drew criticism from UK leaders and Jewish groups.
UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer condemned the ban as 'wrong' and emphasized the importance of allowing all fans to enjoy football without fear of violence.
The UK government has since engaged with Israeli authorities to understand the circumstances of the Tel Aviv violence.
Maccabi fans were previously involved in violent incidents during a match against Ajax in Amsterdam, indicating a history of security concerns.

namedEntities.name: Tel Aviv
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A city in Israel where the soccer derby took place
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The location of the match, where public disorder occurred between rival football clubs, highlighting local tensions and security issues.

namedEntities.name: Hapoel
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An Israeli football club based in Tel Aviv
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: One of the two competing teams in the derby; criticized police actions, highlighting the conflict between public safety and sporting freedom.

namedEntities.name: Maccabi
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An Israeli football club based in Tel Aviv
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The other team in the derby; its fans were involved in prior violent incidents, adding context to current security concerns.

namedEntities.name: Bloomfield Stadium
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A shared stadium in Tel Aviv used by Hapoel and Maccabi
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The venue where the match was scheduled, and where fan clashes and violence occurred, leading to the match cancellation.

namedEntities.name: Israel Police
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The law enforcement agency in Israel
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Responsible for managing the public order during the match and making the decision to cancel it due to safety risks.

namedEntities.name: West Midlands Police
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The law enforcement agency in England
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Made a decision to ban Maccabi fans from a match in England due to prior incidents, showing cross-border security concerns.

namedEntities.name: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The head of the UK government
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Condemned the ban on Maccabi fans in England, emphasizing the importance of fan safety and inclusivity in football.

namedEntities.name: Aston Villa
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An English football club in the Premier League
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The venue where a previously banned Maccabi match was scheduled, linking the event to international fan security issues.

namedEntities.name: Ajax (Dutch football club)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Maccabi fans were involved in violent incidents during a match against Ajax in Amsterdam, highlighting a history of fan violence.

namedEntities.name: Europa League
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The context of the match where Maccabi fans were banned, showing international security concerns.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Tel Aviv soccer derby between Hapoel and Maccabi was canceled after violent riots involving fans and police at Bloomfield Stadium, with 12 civilians and three officers injured. Police cited the danger of human life and use of pyrotechnics and smoke grenades as justification. Hapoel criticized the police response, calling it excessive and indicative of a militarized approach. This event follows a prior ban of Maccabi fans in England due to security concerns, which drew criticism from UK leaders like Prime Minister Keir Starmer, who emphasized fan safety and inclusivity. The incident also reflects a history of violent fan behavior, including during a match against Ajax in Amsterdam, indicating broader issues of fan safety and inter-community tensions in international football.
title: Tel Aviv Soccer Derby Canceled by Police Due to 'Violent Riots'
